Authors:
Matteo Montagna, Valeria Mereghetti, Valeria Lencioni,
Bruono Rossaro
Title:
Integrated taxonomy of Alpine midges (Diptera;
Chironomidae
Keywords:
insects, molecular taxonomy, morphospecies, larvae, DNA
barcoding
Abstract:
Expeditious and efficient DNA-based tools are recommended
to evaluate insect biodiversity of high-altitude streams. In the present
study, mainly focused on larvae of the genus Diamesa Meigen 1835
(Diptera; Chironomidae), the congruence between
morphologically/molecularly delimited species as well as performances in
taxonomic assignments were evaluated. A fragment of the mitochondrial
cox1 gene was obtained from 112 larvae, pupae and adults (Diamesinae,
Orthocladiinae and Tanypodinae). On the basis of morphological
characters 102 specimens were attributed to 16 species, the remaining
ten specimens were identified at the genus level. Molecular species
delimitation was performed using distance-based, with no a priori
assumptions, and coalescent tree-based methods. Distance based method
identified 23 putative species, while the tree-based approaches
identified between 25-26 entities, nearly identical results. Almost all
the recovered molecular species perfectly match with the identified
morphospecies. Within the cinerella group, cases of discrepancy arose:
i) the two morphologically separate species D. cinerella and D. tonsa
are neither monophyletic nor diagnosable showing low values of between
taxa nucleotide mean divergence (0.94 %); ii) few cases of larvae
morphological misidentification were observed. These discrepancies led
to the discovery of colour gradient between the setae submenti and genal
setae as a valid character in discriminating larvae of D. zernyi and D.
cinerella groups. DNA barcodes performances resulted elevated: average
accuracy of ~89% and precision of ~99%. On the basis of the present
data, we can thus conclude that molecular identification represents a
promising tool that could be effectively adopted in evaluating
biodiversity of high-altitude streams.
